Since there's no odds when performing deterministic actions with open information, risk vs reward decision making is replaced by binary "yes/automatic" or "no/impossible" processing. And there's even a backtrack rule that allows the real active player to redo his whole turn from the start, yay!

Besides dispensable day & night cards, the wound mechanic was a neat idea to hinder possibilities before experiencing how limited your possibilities are at any given time. With only a single different card per deck, knights are obviously empty shells so they surely are balanced? Try winning against Greendick or battle thonged Arythea. At least, you'll have the pleasure of leading armies of powerful golems, arcane mages and the likes that will serve once then as meat shields. Mostly though, you'll try to desperately move your lazy ass a couple hexes a turn, go on adventures without narrative wishing to discover easy preys on accessible terrain, draw the right cards at the right time and enter villages and monasteries that will offer the same companions and upgrades as any other on the map.

Mage Knight Board Game is a problem. There are a few reasons. One of those is a matter of expectations. People were comparing it to Magic Realm right off the bat, as a large scale sandbox fantasy adventure game. Some even called it a streamlined MR. This is not the case. MR is sandbox-y because you actually have the freedom to do what you want. MK un-streamlines the process by introducing deck-building which restricts your actions each turn. No longer can you do what you want (and possibly fail, but at least you can try). Now, you need to draw the right cards at the right time (more on that later).

Another touted expectation for the game is that it is the ideal solo experience. Again, not really the case. The reason that it works well solo is that there is no downtime with no other players, and each additional player slows the game down immensely. Yet without interaction, the game is reduced to an excessive puzzle that plays you as much as you play it, rather than a game with meaningful decisions.

I guess I could note some good things. The locations are (in the abstract) thematic and logical. In fact, a lot of the individual isolated mechanics are thematic and logical. It's the combination that seems like a problem. The game requires a commitment to learn deck manipulation for each of the numerous situations you get yourself into, and those commitments are full of losses until you find your footing. This is not to say that games should be easy, but games should be scaled. MKBG has lots of scale: the plethora of scenarios is impressive and worthy of praise on its own. The scale of the game requires tweaking, else the commitment the game requires may never be completed.

This game has a strong mix of mechanisms. You and your fellow players explore a hex map with your character mini, equipped with asymmetric decks of character abilities. As you explore, kill monsters and gain experience points, you get opportunities to do a little bit of deck-building.

Downtime between turns in this game is massive because turns are long and procedural, particularly once battles with monsters start and you have absolutely nothing to think about during that time. Additionally, the maps generally extend in a cone-shape, which puts players later in turn order at a large disadvantage. I think the game works best with 1 or 2 players at most. Monsters are also represented by little circular pog-like tokens, with many tiny icons. Each icon indicates a monster ability, so expect to be re-checking them a lot in the rulebook during play.

Way too much fiddle for an adventure game, one that also struggles to deliver compelling narratives that reward your investment of time and energy. I don't care how deep or modular the system is. There are better puzzle box optimization exercises, and better adventure games that feel, ya know, adventuresome and thematic.

I had heard great things about this game, but it's not for me. It reminds me of aspects of Spirit Island, Gloomhaven, and the video game Heroes of Might & Magic, but I like all of those so much more. The tokens & maps look like they come from decades before. The symbology isn't great. The rules are fiddly and dense in this game. I prefer my complicated games to be cooperative. The game gives you open world choices on how to improve your character by exploring, choosing to fight enemies, hiring recruits, leveling up, gaining spells, etc, but it feels like too much work and not enough variety. The adventuring theme feels shallow; there's very little narrative to it. Maybe the only unique thing about the theme is that you are a mage who can take on whole cities by yourself. You definitely feel your power increase over the course of the game, but there's not that much variety in the cards. You can use each card in 3 ways typically. Every card can be turned sideways for a point of move, influence (I.E. currency), attack, or block. It's base ability will be better than that, but more focused. And you can power it with the right color mana to get the better ability on the bottom of the card instead. Mana come in 3 forms. Each turn there are 3 shared mana dice and you are allowed to use one on your turn. Some abilities will give you a mana token, which only sticks around for the turn. Some give you a mana crystal, which can be saved. Movement costs vary depending on the terrain type. And some enemies will attack you if you move adjacent to them. You can spend some movement points on exploring the map when you are on the edge of some sides. You have no choice in how to orient them. They have symbols on the edges that you have to line up. And often you will add tokens face down when a map tile is revealed, and must get adjacent to the token to see what it is. You can do multiple actions with a location usually. You could get quick rewards that lower your reputation making it so recruits won't deal with you. The game wants you to do a balance of good & bad things. Each turn you play cards from your hand until you decide you are done. You must do all your moves first and then can take one action. Unused cards may be carried over to the next turn or discarded. Once you or the NPC timer have gone through your deck, day turns to night and you do it all again. And that repeats for a length specified by the scenario. Forests cost much more movement at night, but deserts cost much less. The sun mana is a wild mana during the day, but useless at night. The dark mana is useless during the day, but can be used for some spells at night. The game gets complex for combat. And not necessarily in an interesting way. There is at least no dice rolling. Though you may go into some fights without knowing what stats you need. The game has many scenarios and ways to tweak the rules, but it just doesn't attract me enough to learn it more. Spirit Island scratches the same itch with more variety in the synergetic choices in less time. Normally if I'm playing solo, I'd prefer a video game anyway.

There's a lot of great things to say about Mage Knight... and a lot of not-so-great things to say. After a few games, here's my big takeaways:

1) There's a lot you can do in Mage Knight. The game wants to give you the maximum amount of adventure it can with the materials it has. It gives me a similar sense of adventure and scale that comes from a vast role-playing video game like Skyrim. This is what makes the game seriously awesome imo.

2) It's extremely complex, to the point of being bloated. The game introduces mechanic after mechanic, and they all interact in weird, gritty ways that could've been streamlined out. Another point I want to make about the complexity is that there are about a billion different ways of making even the most basic move, which in turn makes sequencing your actions an absolute nightmare.

3) Excellent player progression. There's a number of ways in which you can get more powerful over the course of the game, and they all feel good. With some cleverness and a bit of luck, you can pull off some absolutely insane feats that make your friends green with envy.

4) I know I'm not saying anything new here, but the rulebook is exceptionally terrible. I think whoever wrote it (presumably Vlaada Chvatil) probably realized that Mage Knight is a complicated game, and opted to make the rulebook as "fluffy" as possible by chocking it full of unnecessary clarifications and pointless descriptions. Both rulebooks together are about 30 incredibly-dense pages; succinct writing and a smart use of keywords could've cut them down to 15 or so.

All in all, a flawed masterpiece. Worth diving into, but I wouldn't recommend it to everyone.

I've only played the introductory game of this, so I may warm to it more when I go back for another try, but my initial thoughts aren't so kind. I really want to like the game, as it has so many things going for it, but I found it too obtuse.

Being able to explore this world filled with fantastical locations is great. You have all sorts of options: buying new cards, hiring followers, collecting crystals, sieging castles, sacking monasteries, exploring dungeons, etc. You can decide to be a renowned hero or reviled villain, and both give you advantages. The chrome factor is huge, with bits & chits of all kinds. The day and night phases with different rules are a neat addition.

My first complaint is that combat is really odd and unintuitive. There are the expected ranged and melee phases. Instead of just dealing damage and subtracting armor, you have to go through this arcane procedure to block and see how much damage each participant takes. Then, you can assign some, but not all of it to your followers?
The rules are so generally massive and fiddly that you'll be referring back to the book for lots of questions. They do a good job of putting many things on player-aid cards, but it just isn't enough.

The big problem overshadowing all others, though, is the deckbuilding style. It's a neat idea, but it it doesn't entirely work, esp. not in a game of this length. Remember when I said you had all those cool options during your turn? Well, it turns out you actually don't. Oh, you can gaze at the map and imagine all the stuff you'd like to do, but then you have to look at your hand and discover how little of it you can feasibly attempt. It's great that you can exchange any card for a 1-point action of any type, but this doesn't really solve the problem. You can easily be staring at a bunch of move cards when you're sitting next to the fortress you want to attack. If you move away, you can do something else, but then next turn you'll likely be in the opposite state: with a handful of attack cards and no move to get you adjacent to something to attack. The game is very tactical this way, asking you to decide what the best thing is that you can accomplish this turn. Of course, you can save over cards from turn to turn, so you can plan ahead and spend only some of your cards, saving the rest for a more potent turn next time.
All of this would be entirely fine, if not for one more rule. The day ends when one player exhausts their deck. This means that instead of having the option to take your time, mitigate bad draws, and advance slowly doing incremental things, you're forced to keep pace with the fastest player. Someone is going to get all his/her cards in the perfect order, be able to make best use of all of them, and burn through his/her deck like lightning. If you get your cards in the wrong order or all clumped together, you'll be forced to discard many of them for the generic low-power option, and will fall further and further behind. If you try to mitigate this by playing cautiously and doing small turns, you'll end the day with half your deck left and be no better off. Again, this sort of luck-of-the-draw is entirely expected from deckbuilders, but the problem is that those games generally A. play quickly, not as multi-hour affairs and B. see you cycling through your deck many times (hopefully evening out the luck aspect), not just 3. This even means that adding cool, powerful new cards to your deck isn't that good, since you're still slaved to the pace of the person with the smallest deck and you won't see them more than a couple times max.

We also turned off PvP, and I'm damn glad we did, since continually having to watch your back would make the experience even more painful. It seems like turn order would become king, as it'd be really easy to ambush someone who had depleted their cards and couldn't fight back.

Again, I'm going to have to try this a second time, as there was enough there to intrigue me. But this stuff really stuck out and hurt my enjoyment of it the first time through.

It seems to be the best game as an adventure-type slay monsters and level up type of game. Magic Realm is just too outdated and overly-complex. Dragons Down is a much improved MR, it just isn't as fun as MK. MK, while not perfect, is a reasonable alternative. An Ameritrash game that takes a lot of unnecessary randomness out--a hybrid then? What's more is that it is a good game to play solo, although I much prefer it two player. My gripes with it (admittedly minor) are the ugly card art and miniature figurines. The art is good quality, in fact, but the depiction of human(oid) creatures is where it fails. The art on the cards is very colorful and effective, and certainly is an improvement over cards with no art at all. I don't use the city minis (you really only need to know what color enemy tokens to put out, which could have easily just been depicted on one of the many reference cards), and the mage knight minis would be better as a wooden disc with a sticker depicting the Mage Knight. It could even be double sided, and you flip it over when you pass. But, at least they're prepainted which is a nice improvement over gray monotone.

I'm not a huge fan of deck-building, but there's enough of the game outside of this mechanic to make it fun. It's more hand management than deckbuilding, since you aren't required to discard your hand at the end of your turn, and aside from Wounds, there aren't any completely useless cards (I'm looking at you, Dominion). The icons work well, and I have to mention that the art and site locations on the terrain tiles are of excellent quality and make for very clear gameplay. This game is certainly heavy and fiddly with a few rules exceptions, but it's worth every bit of the struggle to get there. Everything is thematically intuitive as well as important for game balance.

Oh, and in case it matters, I know nothing of the original Mage Knight minis game or the MK setting.
